classes.name: Barbarian
classes.desc: Striding out of the wilderness come ferocious women and indomitable men, barbaric warriors who pit their sinew and will against everything empires and sorcery can throw against them. Some win glory and wealth, while others gain nothing but the grim satisfaction of beating down powerful and terrifying foes.
classes.complexity: The simplest versions of the barbarian are designed for the player who wants to roll dice and slay without worrying too much about the rules. The slightly more complex versions of the barbarian still offer fewer choices during play than most other classes.
classes.playstyle: A barbarian character is straightforward and easy to play. It's a good class for a new player or the player who wants to have fun without worrying much about rules getting in the way of awesome attacks. Unlike most of the other classes, barbarians don't gain powers every level. Instead, most of their extra oomph comes from their class talents. The simplest barbarian player characters keep decisions to a minimum while contributing with mighty attacks and awesome bravado.

keymechanics.title: Rage
keymechanics.desc: At the start of each of your turns, you roll a 1d12 and add the escalation die. If the result is 8+, you are raging this turn and natural odd rolls on your attacks deal double damage (crits deal triple). If you roll a nat 1 you can't rage this turn, and if you roll a nat12 you have 5e-style advantage on your rage attacks.

powers.pwrDesc: You channel the ferocity of dire wolves, dire bears, tigers, or other great wilderness predators. Over the course of each arc, choose a benefit which improves your rage roll, initiative, defenses, or damage.

pwrFeats.feat: Increase the effectiveness of Beast Talent and expand your options available each arc.

powers.pwrDesc: As you miss attacks you can store +2 damage for a subsequent hit, up to +12 (damage increases at even levels: +3/max 18, +4/max 24, etc up to +15/max 90 at lvl 10.)

pwrFeats.feat: Increases the opportunities to add this stacking damage.

powers.pwrDesc: Lets you rage much easier when you take out enemies who started the battle with more health than you. Also grants you regenerative healing.

pwrFeats.feat: Makes it easier to trigger the regeneration.

powers.pwrDesc: Lets you summon ancestral warrior spirits to help you in battle. However, because of the battle warping abilities these additional warriors grant, there are special rules on how it recharges and if it doesn't recharge, you must pick a different talent, your ancestors having helped you all they can.

pwrFeats.feat: Your ancestor spirits always get the benefit of raging.

classes.backgrounds: clan champion, caravan outrider, fur trapper, ice wolf fur trapper, former volcano priest, wasteland survivalist, reluctant gladiator turned eager champion, dire beast hunter, dire beast guardian,

classes.name: Bard
classes.desc: If the gods didn't create the world with a song, that's sure what it sounds like when you hear a mighty bard sing. Bards travel the world, learning and teaching each other the ancient songs and arcane secrets of a hundred lands. They practice an intuitive and nimble sort of arcane magic, using not merely their minds to cast spells but their hearts. Their spells, their swordplay, and their romances all demonstrate not just skill but a certain poetry. The best bards bring out the best in others, inspiring them to overcome all obstacles and then spreading the story in a victory song. The worst bards are manipulative, seductive egomaniacs.
classes.complexity: The bard has a variety of options because each of its talents supply effects that trigger on hitting with an attack or being missed with an attack, along with healing magic that requires the bard to pay attention to what's happening at the table. The bard also has spells, persistent songs, and unique features from their talents. Figuring out how to use these options in combat and in roleplaying is will be fun for a confident player but potentially overwhelming for a first timer. The bard is the class voted most likely to use index cards or some other form of organizing spells, reactions, and options.
classes.playstyle: Bards are magical, musical, playful, helpful, and tricky. Bards are flexible characters with many options in roleplaying situations and in combat. They're not the best character choice for beginning players, but can be a lot of fun for experienced or extroverted players who enjoy mastering different types of abilities.

keymechanics.title: Bardic Talents
keymechanics.desc: Each of the Bard class talents grants several abilities, an additional effect when you hit with a weapon, a healing ability, a reaction when you are missed by an attack, and a special feature just for that talent. Bards have multiple reactions and quick action options in their toolkit. Mastering these is key to the class. When you take feats for the talent, you get the same tier of feat for each ability under that talent.

keymechanics.title: Social Skills
keymechanics.desc: You are able to get +3 to social checks three times per arc, four times at lvl 5 and five times at lvl 8. A feat makes the bonus +5.

powers.pwrDesc: As a Bardic Song, it's tracked separately from your usual spell count. At the beginning of your turn, you see if the spell is sustained, otherwise you get a boosted final effect. Grants your allies +1 to attacks, while the Final Verse gives one ally +2 on their next attack.

pwrFeats.feat: Improve the recharge of the spell, making it more usable more often, and increase the effect.

powers.pwrDesc: Use one of the invocations from the cleric's domain talents. Interpret the invocation favorably. For example, the Healing invocation provides an extra use of the heal spell, so you would gain a single use of the heal spell. The group is still limited to one invocation per party per battle.
You use an ally's icon relationship and get the benefits of a non-combat Icon connection, altering the entire scenario. IE, it can trigger "The Eagles are coming!".

classes.backgrounds: Wandering minstrel, cathedral musician, court jester, court jester, mercenary herald, two time runner-up in the Twisp games of song and satire, tavern owner, failed hedge wizard, frustrated diplomat, spy, royal taster, caravan guide, smuggler, party circuit maven, battle skald, dance instructor, dwarven battle cry instructor.

classes.name: Cleric
classes.desc: All mortals call on the gods, but when a cleric calls, the gods sometimes listen. In the current age the gods are quiet or communicate subtlely, making the few clerics that remain the primary representatives of divine might.
classes.complexity: Slightly more complicated than the Rogue and Sorcerer. Interesting choices include domain invocations that should be cast at the beginning of a battle, maintaining a balance between healing and fighting, and spells that can be cast for power or for broad effect.
classes.playstyle: The decisions necessary to play a cleric skillfully as well as the responsibility of tracking your allies' need for healing suggest that it is a better class for an experienced player. You can shape each battle using one of your invocations, but your choice of invocation won't always be clear. There aren't a ton of decision points, but the ones available influence a lot.

keymechanics.title: Armor OR Vestments
keymechanics.desc: Each cleric chooses whether they will advance their faith as heavily armored warriors with health and recoveries closer to a fighter or as lightly armored spellcasters with an extra at-will spell.

keymechanics.title: Ritual Magic
keymechanics.desc: Essentially allows you to spend one of your limited use spells in order to cast a utility spell over the course of a time period that is out of combat. The most obvious use is Bless in order to be "blessed" with something like waterbreathing.

keymechanics.title: Casting for Broad Effect
keymechanics.desc: Some spells allow you to cast for broad effect, which means they are less potent but effect more targets.

powers.pwrDesc: When you cast a spell besides Heal during a battle that heals yourself or an ally, gain a bonus to the healing based on your Wisdom. The invocation lets you cast Heal an additional time this battle.

pwrFeats.feat: Increase the potency of your Heal spell and the number of free uses.

powers.pwrDesc: You can target more creatures when casting for broad effect. As an Invocation, critical hits against you and your allies deal normal damage instead.

pwrFeats.feat: An ally affected by your broad effect spells can save against a condition or effect on them.

powers.pwrDesc: One ally gets +2 attack bonus until end of the battle or up to three allies get +1 until the end of the battle. At higher levels it also adds temp hp

Two creatures get two rerolls of a d20 or five creatures get one reroll of a d20 during a battle. You cast this as a free action during initiative. This is notable because 5e-style advantage is an INCREDIBLY rare bonus in 13th age if you're not a lucky barbarian.

pwrFeats.feat: The first two rerolls used by the group that miss don't use up the reroll.

classes.backgrounds: village healer, archivist, military chaplain, temple guard, bartender, reformed thief, abyssal survivor, wasteland prophet, dwarven hierophant, initiate of the Stellar Chorus, bishop of Foothold, multiversal pantheist, Cathedral guide, tutored by angels.

classes.name: Fighter
classes.complexity: Simple to play but can askyou to choose between offense and defense maneuvers. The Combat Rhythm talent rewards fighters who maintain balanced offense and defense.
classes.playstyle: Playing a fighter is relatively simple. If you decide against using Combat Rhythm, you choose which maneuver you want to use, then attack. If you do have Combat Rhythm, you're choosing from fewer options each turn but have a higher chance to hit.

keymechanics.title: Fighter Maneuvers
keymechanics.desc: In a lot of ways 13th Age Fighters operate more like if 5e Battlemaster was the base class. Some manuevers are at-will and others have limitations on use per battle or arc.

keymechanics.title: Fighter Talents
keymechanics.desc: As you level up, fighters get access to more class talents as a key feature.

keymechanics.title: Zenith Talents
keymechanics.desc: At level 10, if the group earns an incremental advancement, you can take one last Fighter Talent or turn a magic piece of equipment you have sentient and give it an additional ability.

powers.pwrDesc: After one of your maneuvers drops an enemy to 0 you can make a basic attack against another valid target. Extra attack is NOT a thing in 13th Age so this is one of the few sources of extra attacks.

pwrFeats.feat: Allows for mobility between the attacks or increases the accuracy and damage of the Cleave attack.

powers.pwrDesc: After you use a maneuver, you note whether it's offence or defense, and set your Rhythm to the other. You deal half damage with defense maneuvers, but when you use a combat maneuver that matches your current Rhythm, you gain 5e Advantage.

pwrFeats.feat: Lets you keep offense if you miss, start the battle in defense, or help you trigger a crit.

powers.pwrDesc: Twice per battle you deal extra damage on a hit based on the escalation die.
Rearrange yourself, an enemy, and any allies to be engaged or not engaged with each other.

pwrFeats.feat: Allows more uses as to ignore and break grapples.

classes.backgrounds: traveling swordmaster, mercenary captain, sea raider, shieldwall spearman, Spine Mountains explorer, Crossroads bouncer, well-dressed thug, city guardsman, Sea Wall veteran, former gladiator, former orc captive, bankrupt nobleman, duelist, underworld goblin-hunter, caravan guard, former legionnaire.

classes.name: Paladin
classes.desc: In every age, extraordinary men and women have stepped forward to carry the battle flag of justice. By the will of the gods, paladins are both protectors and avengers whose campaigns of awesome justice serve as warnings to any who threaten those under their protection. The people depend on them, lords celebrate them, and monsters hate them. People have never needed paladins more than they do now.
classes.complexity: Relies on a short list of class talents instead of powers. At adventurer-tier, it's the simplest class to play for newcomers.
classes.playstyle: Like the barbarian, the paladin is simple to play. Your choices during combat come from your talents since you don't choose new attacks or spells as you rise in level. Most every attack you make uses your basic melee attack, but you can augment it by using Smite or one of the other abilities from your talents. Paladins who want a bit more complexity can choose talents that let them cast a cleric spell or use a cleric domain.

keymechanics.title: Smite
keymechanics.desc: Once per battle as a free action before you make an attack roll, you can declare you're using a Smite. Then you add a bonus to the damage. If you miss, you do not expend the Smite. Feats add bonuses to Smites, more damage, and more uses.

keymechanics.title: Lay on Hands
keymechanics.desc: You roll one of your recoveries and you or an ally gets the healing. When it's someone else, there's an extra bonus based on your Charisma. Feats increase uses per arc. Most, if not all, other healing abilities use the recipient's recoveries, whereas Lay on Hands lets you use yours for someone else.

powers.pwrDesc: Your roll saves at the start of your turn, instead of the end, letting you use your turn normally if you succeed or ignore ongoing damage.

pwrFeats.feat: You get bonuses to the save or free uses.

powers.pwrDesc: When you drop an enemy, you don't expend the use of your Smite.

pwrFeats.feat: Give you additional uses of Smite the more damaged you are.

powers.pwrDesc: You basically magically transform into an elder dragon with all sorts of movement and protection benefits. Also grants a unique version of a high level sorcerer spell.

pwrFeats.feat: Increases your icon relationship with the Great Gold Wyrm or The Three equivalent.

classes.backgrounds: City guard, combat medic, bodyguard, outlaw hunter, Sea Wall captain, Clockwork Citadel archeologist, Matriarch courtier, Heartlands Inquisitor, veteran of the orc wars, incursion commando, ex-priest of the Epiphany.

classes.name: Ranger
classes.desc: Some rangers get their training in an official ranger corps, serving a legitimate authority. Others are initiates into half-wild gangs, resourceful nomads who know more ancient secrets than their rough manner might suggest. Rangers from different lands or traditions respect each other, though they can still be ruthless rivals. In the wilderness, rangers are held in awe, provided the common people even know they're there. In the city, rangers are notorious for complaining about the conditions of urban life, but they are renowned as outlandish party guests.
classes.complexity: Relies on base attacks augmented by class talents instead of a power list. The simpler ranger characters are based on Hunter Talents that provide options for higher damage. More complex rangers use more Warrior Talents that provide access to extra Skirmisher turns, but even then, rangers are arguably simpler to play than fighters. (A ranger using Control the Range a lot might lose the argument.)
classes.playstyle: Like the barbarian, the ranger can be simple to play. Most of your choices in play come from your class talents since you don't choose new attacks or spells as you gain levels. Most every attack you make uses your basic melee or ranged attack. Depending on which talents you choose, you'll have access to actions that increase the amount of damage you deal with a specific attack or that give you a second turn.

keymechanics.title: Tracker
keymechanics.desc: Lets you reroll a wilderness-related skill check at +3. Represents your skills in the outdoors. Feats give it more uses and effectiveness.

keymechanics.title: Lethal Hunter
keymechanics.desc: Deal extra damage on an attack, based on your level. The more Hunter talents you have, the more uses you get. Feats give you more uses and more consistent damage.

keymechanics.title: Skirmisher
keymechanics.desc: Gives you a second turn with a move and standard action later in the round. The more Warrior talents you have, the more uses you get. Feats expand what you can do on the turn and make it easier to retain it if something goes wrong.

powers.pwrDesc: You have an animal companion who fights alongside you. However, mechanically it is more like a special attack or ability you have. This prevents a slow down in combat as well as prevents your beloved companion from being annihilated by a dragon's stray breath weapon. The animal companion can also get random abilities to boost its effectiveness.

pwrFeats.feat: There are so many feats and choices available, suffice to say, you

powers.pwrDesc: Drops your damage die down one level and you get to attack a second time on a natural even roll.

pwrFeats.feat: Lets you move between attacks or let you use it on an odd roll sometimes.

powers.pwrDesc: Gives you a group of four spells you can cast one from once per arc, but you can't cast that spell again until you cast the other remaining spells in the list. At 5th level you can cast two per arc (completing the cycle in two arcs).

pwrFeats.feat: Lets you cast an Elemental Nature spell in the cycle this arc when you fail a death save.

classes.backgrounds: tracker, bounty hunters, members of secret orders of frontier guardians, agents of druidic circles, survivors of distant massacres, beast slayers, tree dwellers, initiates of the golden bough, woodsy assassins, dwellers on the sea wall, behemoth tribefolk, wanderers, and occasionally even secret monarchs of vanished kingdoms.

classes.name: Rogue
classes.desc: Rogues are a mixed bag. Some are thugs who have learned enough tricks to get a step ahead of the other thugs. A few are mad, driven by a reckless sense of adventure. Most are quick with a smile, a blade, and a getaway.
classes.complexity: About as complicated as the the more complicated versions of the fighter. You track whether or not you have momentum, are constantly disengaging, and trying to use your Sneak Attack or Rush Attack damage effectively. Using Shadow Walk to disappear from most fights for a round simplifies the rogue, though it may complicate the lives of the rogues' allies.
classes.playstyle: Rogue can be a challenge to play if you choose the Rush Attack option instead of Sneak Attack. Sneak Attack powers require the rogue to team up with allies, slightly simpler than the movement required for Rush Attacks. Momentum powers depend heavily on whether you last hit an enemy or were hit yourself.

keymechanics.title: Momentum
keymechanics.desc: You gain momentum by hitting an enemy and lose momentum when you are hit by an attack. When you use a momentum power, you retain momentum unless the power specifies that you spend it..

keymechanics.title: Rush Attack OR Sneak Attack
keymechanics.desc: For Rush Attack, you gain additional damage on your first attack with a new target this turn. For Sneak Attack you deal extra damage once a round against an enemy one of your allies is engaged with.

powers.pwrDesc: You can use your Intelligence wherever a rogue attack, talent or power says to use Charisma.

pwrFeats.feat: Improves mental defenses.

powers.pwrDesc: A momentum power where you spend momentum. Once per battle, you take half damage when hit against AC.

pwrFeats.feat: Expands what sort of attacks trigger Roll With It use.

powers.pwrDesc: A momentum power where you spend momentum. You make a number of attacks equal to the escalation die, ignoring critical hits. This is an arc/desperate power, which means it is usable once per arc but it recharges when you get a Skull (fail a death save) or spend your last recovery, whichever is first.

pwrFeats.feat: Deals damages on misses and lets you score critical hits.

classes.backgrounds: Street thug, cat burglar, diplomat, professional gambler, Idresan customs agent, courtier, jewel thief, acrobat, con artist, bartender, incursion infiltrator, temple spy master, thieves guild organizer, pirate, dandy, rat catcher.

classes.name: Sorceror
classes.desc: Sorcerers are notoriously reckless with their spells. Wizards say that a sorcerer doesn't so much cast a spell as uncork it. Some say you never talk to the same sorcerer twice; others say not even once.
classes.complexity: Slightly complex because of the option to cast spells for double the effect in two rounds by more or less taking a round off. In a sense, the sorcerer might be simpler to play than the rogue, and it's definitely simpler than the cleric. But the decisions you make while playing a sorcerer are important, each choice has a lot of impact. It's easy to play a sorcerer. It's harder to play a sorcerer optimally.
classes.playstyle: A sorcerer makes a small number of big decisions. Can you afford to gather power for a big effect next round? Or do your allies need you to blast an enemy right now? And once you've gathered power, you need to pick the right target for your double-strength spell. Meanwhile, monsters engage you, and sometimes you are forced to accept an opportunity attack to get your big spell off Players who can handle dice swinginess may enjoy the sorcerer more. If you're not that type, steer clear of the more chaotic powers.

keymechanics.title: Spell Keywords
keymechanics.desc: Some sorcerer spells have "Breath Weapon", "Chain", "Random Energy" keywords. Breath Weapon spells apply escalation die to their crit range. Chain spells attack the nearest valid target who hasn't been hit yet on a natural even roll. Random Energy spells deal a random damage type.

keymechanics.title: Gather Power
keymechanics.desc: You spend your standard action gathering power. On your next turn, if you cast a damaging spell the damage is doubled otherwise the gathered power is lost. There's also the chance for ad-hoc effects at GM's discretion. After spending your gathered power, you can use a quick action on the same turn for one of your sorcerer talents' Overspill effect.

keymechanics.title: Sorcerer Spell Feats
keymechanics.desc: These operate like Metamagic in 5e. But when you take the feat, the spells you cast that have those feats, such as Reverberate, will trigger that effect when you cast the spell. In this way one feat upgrades a class of spells.

powers.pwrDesc: Once per arc as a quick action, roll 2 dice and choose one to gain a random demonic ability from a table. As an Overspill effect, you deal random damage to multiple enemies.

pwrFeats.feat: YOU ARE NOT LIMITED TO ONE HERITAGE TALENT. Each one is connected to a magically inclined Icon. This makes the Sorcerer the core class that is the most defined by the Icons of a setting.
You get the abilties of both dice, the overspill effect hits more targets, and you can just choose an ability at escalation 6+.

powers.pwrDesc: After choosing your spells for an arc, you gain a random spell you COULD have picked but didn't. Overspill increases everyone's crit range by 1.

pwrFeats.feat: You exclude at-wills from the random spell selection.

powers.pwrtitle: Breath of Blue Lightning (1st level spell)
powers.pwrDesc: Deal damage to a nearby enemy targeting their physical defense (ie, their "dodge armor") and put a Spark effect on them that deals ongoing damage to them and a closest nearby ally of theirs.

pwrFeats.feat: Deals additional damage and adds a small explosion when the target makes the save against Spark.

powers.pwrDesc: An out of combat spell, but unlike a normal ritual there's no skill check involved. You gain a powerful magical effect associated with a randomly determined Icon (from the options available as a heritage talent). The effect could be a powerful ally, temporary magic item, a spell, or a special capacity against an upcoming enemy.

pwrFeats.feat: Deals additional damage and adds a small explosion when the target makes the save against Spark.

classes.backgrounds: Tribal shaman, former child avatar, Yazatli pirate captain, spellarena gladiator, failed wizard, Silent City guard, elemental hunter.

classes.name: Wizard
classes.desc: Wizards are the masters of arcane energy. They use geometry, symbology, occult numerology, and a complex grammatical system to describe magic and thereby control it. They fill their heavy, locked spellbooks with crabbed writing, secret codes, and convoluted designs.
classes.complexity: Rivals the bard as the most complex class, especially if you choose all the options that allow improvisation and ad-libbing. Without those free-form talents, it's no more difficult than the sorcerer.
classes.playstyle: The wizard is designed for experienced players who like a bit of improvisation. Most of the wizard's spells can only be used once per arc, so timing matters. If you want to play the simplest possible wizard, choose the Abjuration, Evocation, and Familiar talents. To play as the flexible spellcaster who finds unique and amusing answers to problems, choose Cantrip Mastery, High Arcana, and Vance's Polysyllabic Verbalizations.

keymechanics.title: Cantrips
keymechanics.desc: You have access to every Cantrip (these are different than at-will spells!) and you can use a number of them equal to your Intelligence modifier, resetting each battle. These are spells like Alarm, Knock, Light, and Mage Hand. A lot of utility that isn't worth a leveled spell slot but still useful.

keymechanics.title: Ritual Magic
keymechanics.desc: Essentially allows you to spend one of your limited use spells in order to cast a utility spell over the course of a time period that is out of combat. The most obvious use is the Utility Spell you get in order to pull a tool out of your proverbial toolbox.

keymechanics.title: Cyclic Spells
keymechanics.desc: These are spells that you can always cast once per battle, but if you cast them when the escalation die is 2, 4, or 6+, you do not expend the usage.

keymechanics.title: Judicious Casting
keymechanics.desc: Spells that have different effect when you're casting carefully or recklessly. Like FIREBALL!

powers.pwrDesc: Essentially, you can cast spells at a higher level if you give it an over the top name. Such as Rodrigo's Scintillating Plasms instead of Fireball.

pwrFeats.feat: Gives you additional uses based on your Charisma. Yes. Your CHARISMA.

powers.pwrDesc: Any wizard can take this feat, it gives you Magic Missile as a quick action spell in addition to your other spells. When you cast it, you roll to determine how many rounds of combat you can cast magic missile this battle, then the level determines how many 5 damage missiles you fire each use. For example, at 5th level you can use the spell 1d6 rounds with 2 missiles each time.

pwrFeats.feat: You have to take the adventurer feat to even use this spell, and the other feats increase the number of missiles and casts per arc.

powers.pwrDesc: Not so much a specific spell, but when you pick your spells you may choose Utility Spell instead of one of the other options. Depending on your level that will give you access to spells like disguise self, feather fall, levitate that you don't need to dedicate a specific slot to.

pwrFeats.feat: Lets you access more uses of Utility Spell depending on the tier (adventurer, champion, or epic)

powers.pwrDesc: Attack 1d3+1 targets. You can choose to cast recklessly and attack 1d4 additional targets, but if you miss one of your allies take a quarter damage if they were engaged with that target.. Deals 10d10 fire damage and 10 ongoing fire damage.

pwrFeats.feat: You can wait to cast recklessly until you know how many initial targets you have. Gives the spell a recharge if cast recklessly (you roll to see if you get it back after each battle while it's expended).

classes.backgrounds: Magical prodigy, spell thief, hedge wizard, chronomancer's apprentice, Heartlands City Guard, transformed familiar, behemoth cleaner, ship's wizard, Gold Coast veteran, royal poisoner.
